title: Church warden jailed for life for murdering elderly university lecturer
text:
Benjamin Field was jailed for at least 36 years for the murder of Peter Farquhar (Picture: PA)

A sadistic church warden who murdered his elderly lover to inherit his house and money following a campaign of cruel manipulation has been jailed for at least 36 years.

Benjamin Field, 28, seduced lonely university lecturer Peter Farquhar, 69, persuading him to write him into his will before poisoning him.

He then set his sights on another elderly neighbour, 83-year-old Ann Moore-Martin, luring her into a sexual relationship in a similar attempt to inherit her home.

Field ‘gaslighted’ Ms Moore-Martin, a deeply religious former headteacher, by writing messages on her mirrors purporting to be from God.

Jailing Field for life at Oxford Crown Court, Mr Justice Sweeney said: ‘It has been an extraordinary case, perhaps which if written as a novel you could not believe it was true, but it was.’

Field killed the lecturer so he could inherit his house and money (Picture: PA)

He poisoned Mr Farquhar in the hope his death woul;d like like suicide or an accident (Picture: PA)

Mr Farquhar, who was torn about his sexuality because of his religion, died in October 2015 while Miss Moore-Martin died in May 2017 from natural causes.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Field secretly gave Mr Farquhar drugs and spiked his whisky, hoping that his eventual death at his hands would look like suicide or an accident.

It was only when the Baptist minister’s son began targeting Ms Moore-Martin, in the village of Maids Moreton, Buckinghamshire, that his wicked scheme began to unravel.

Mr Justice Sweeney said Field ‘clearly enjoyed the cruelty’ of brainwashing Mr Farquhar, best illustrated during one incident where he surreptitiously drugged the author ahead of the launch of one of his books, resulting in his ‘complete humiliation’.

‘Your purpose in drugging him, and in what you said to those who endeavoured to treat him when, in consequence of the drugs, he was ill, was to lay the ground so that your murder of him in due course would appear to have been him having drunk himself to death whilst alone,’ the judge added.

Field went to Mr Farquhar’s home on Sunday October 25 and covertly gave him Dalmane while getting him to drink strong whiskey.

‘I have no doubt that, if it was necessary, you then finished him off by suffocating him in a way that left no trace,’ the judge said.

His plan initially worked, with Field inheriting £20,000 along with a further £142,000 from his share of the proceeds of the lecturer’s house before turning his attention to Ms Moore-Martin.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Similarly ‘lonely’ by the time they met, Field ‘set about seducing her too’ in a drive to inherit her £300,000 home.

‘Before you murdered Peter Farquhar, you were delivering cards to her, giving her gifts, researching sex with the elderly on the internet, and suggesting that she watch a film that portrayed a relationship between an older woman and a younger man,’ said Mr Justice Sweeney.

‘Ultimately, in November 2015, a month after the murder, you began a sexual relationship with her.’

Mr Farquhar was a university lecturer and author (Picture: PA)

The judge said he was satisfied that Field, if necessary, ‘then finished him off by suffocating him in a way that left no trace’ (Picture: PA)

By mid-September of the following year, Field began daubing messages on her mirrors, persuading her they were from God and that he was receiving them too.

Ms Moore-Martin eventually changed her will in early February 2017 before changing it back when Field’s dishonesty was exposed and an investigation launched.

She died from natural causes later that year.

Defending, David Jeremy QC cited a letter penned by Field’s parents, Beverley and Baptist minister Ian, in which they described how their ‘intelligent’ and ‘educated’ son was capable of compassionate behaviour.

‘He chose to apply those gifts towards the manipulation and humiliation of his victims, leading to the murder of Peter Farquhar, the degradation of Ann Moore-Martin and the causing of irreparable harms to the victims, their families and those who are close to them,’ he said.

Advertisement

‘The real motive was to make himself feel good about himself by deceiving and debasing others by being the only one who knew what he was doing, by gaining pleasure, not by sharing as other do, but by creating a world that only he inhabited, in which he was both performer and audience – the world of interiority.

‘It would be far too simplistic to present this case as a conflict between good and evil.

‘It was a combination of circumstances that led him into a downward spiral of behaviour in which he progressively lost touch with any sense of decency or morality.’

He added of the victims: ‘They shared the wish to believe that they could be loved and desired by a much younger man and that wish in them was so strong that they suspended their disbelief.’

A message written by Field to Ms Moore-Martin reading ‘All that you give him he will return tenfold’ (Picture: PA)

Another read ‘Your intentions are holy, your work’s not yet done, take care and complete the task given to you by the Lord’ (Picture: PA)

‘Your soul will proceed directly to heaven, her soul to joy, his to perfection. This good you will can never be undone, peace is your is in me, your Lord. Amen’ (Picture: PA)

Mr Justice Sweeney said Field ‘lived by deception and deceit’ and had been a ‘well-practised and able liar’.

Advertisement

‘You further admitted how you could manipulate and manoeuvre people, however sceptical they may have been, to achieve your ends without ever asking them to do so directly,’ he said.

‘You were, you accepted, a snake talker, as you were able to build pressure on your victims to believe what you needed them the believe and then to do whatever you needed them to do.

‘The evidence at trial clearly demonstrated grandiosity, a sense of superiority towards others, the exploitation of others to achieve personal gain, the need to belittle and humiliate others, fixation on fantasies of power and success, intelligence, a need for admiration from others, and a sense of entitlement together with an unwillingness to empathise with the feelings, needs and wishes of others.’

Field, of Wellingborough Road, Olney, Buckinghamshire, previously pleaded guilty to defrauding Ms Moore-Martin of £4,000 to buy a car and £27,000 for a dialysis machine.

He also admitted two burglaries and the two fraudulent relationships.

The jury cleared him of conspiracy to murder Miss Moore-Martin and the alternative charge of attempted murder. He was also found not guilty of possession of an article for the use in fraud.

description: Benjamin Field seduced lonely university lecturer Peter Farquhar, persuading him to write him into his will before poisoning him.
